TopicTitle: Possible ways to add other Solar Systems

Articles.Content:
As we know, additional solar systems aren't going to be around anytime soon due to it being a lot of work. But, as shown by the genius who made KSP 64 bit work for windows, there are easy ways to do things that work just as well and now I believe the devs have said they are making KSP 64-bit for a future update.

See here for 64-bit stuff

The best solution to a problem is usually the easiest one.
GLaDoS from Portal 2

Now, I was wondering if there are any suggestions from the community that would make adding new systems easier and ways of getting there that don't "ruin" the game.

To start, I have one of my own. Treat solar systems like planets around a point of gravity. To achieve this change Kerbol to be just a point of gravity in space (or something else, I don't know), then add a new Kerbol and put it in orbit around it with the planets and stuff in orbit around that. Similar things have been done by members of the community using Planetfactory CE but the solar systems have always orbited the original Kerbol star. Also, Wormholes...

Hope everyone has great ideas!

I really don't see a need to implement orbits for stars in KSP. The distances are so large and the gravitational forces so small that the stars wouldn't move perceptibly even after several decades.

Thus my vision for multiple stars is to first have Career missions wherein you unlock and launch a space telescope to look for exoplanets. The Tracking Station would then include a small menu somewhere to pick a "known" star system (or double-click a "star" icon in the background). It would simulate in its own space, within which neither Kerbol nor any of its planets are loaded or simulated so as to keep memory usage reasonable. When viewing it in the Tracking Station, all the planets would be visible but only as "dots" until you launch a ship to go there. Once you do, you could either bring a telescope with you to survey all the planets at once or just encounter and survey them one at a time. When a planet is surveyed in this way, the rest of its properties are generated and made visible in the tracking station (similar to what asteroids do).

Discover too many exoplanets, of course, and you'll start eating up hard drive space as often happens in Spore.

Possibly the exoplanet generation code can be non-randomized so that everyone gets the same potential set of systems and can share their discoveries a la Space Engine.

P.S. Going to the other systems would either need a warp drive, a lot of patience, or... a new timewarp factor (or two) that only works in the Space Center or interstellar space.
